articles.headline: Workers Overdose on the Job, and Employers Struggle to Respond
articles.snippet: Many businesses are ill-equipped or unwilling to deal with opioid addiction even as it has driven up health costs and hurt productivity.
articles.abstract: Many businesses are ill-equipped or unwilling to deal with opioid addiction even as it has driven up health costs and hurt productivity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jimmy Sullivan prepared for his job as a bricklayer the same way every morning for years: injecting a shot of heroin before leaving his car.

articles.headline: Rod Rosenstein Suggested Secretly Recording Trump and Discussed 25th Amendment
articles.snippet: In the turbulent days after the firing of James B. Comey, the deputy attorney general appeared conflicted about his role and wanted to expose administration dysfunction, people around him said.
articles.abstract: In the turbulent days after the firing of James B. Comey, the deputy attorney general appeared conflicted about his role and wanted to expose administration dysfunction, people around him said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The deputy attorney general, Rod J. Rosenstein, suggested last year that he secretly record President Trump in the White House to expose the chaos consuming the administration, and he discussed recruiting cabinet members to invoke the 25th Amendment to remove Mr. Trump from office for being unfit.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Michelle Obama’s Big Book Rollout: ‘It’s Like You’re Looking at a Madonna Tour’
articles.snippet: In advance of the publication of Mrs. Obama’s memoir, “Becoming,” Live Nation, Ticketmaster and Hearst are helping with the former first lady’s rock-star-style return to the public sphere.
articles.abstract: In advance of the publication of Mrs. Obama’s memoir, “Becoming,” Live Nation, Ticketmaster and Hearst are helping with the former first lady’s rock-star-style return to the public sphere.
articles.lead_paragraph: A fifth-row seat at the Barclays Center goes for $1,256.00. A seat in the front row, with a “meet & greet package” thrown in, will cost you up to $3,000. Wheelchair seating in the back of the house is listed at $400, while a spot in the upper tiers could be had for $29.50.

articles.headline: Tariffs to Raise Cost of Rebuilding After Hurricane Florence
articles.snippet: Homeowners and businesses will have to pay more for lumber, steel, aluminum and other materials because of President Trump’s trade policy.
articles.abstract: Homeowners and businesses will have to pay more for lumber, steel, aluminum and other materials because of President Trump’s trade policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the floodwaters from Hurricane Florence recede and rebuilding kicks into high gear, homeowners and businesses will face an additional burden as tariffs imposed by the Trump administration drive up the cost of construction materials.

articles.headline: The Death Toll for Afghan Forces Is Secret. Here’s Why.
articles.snippet: The Taliban is killing Afghan soldiers and police officers in record numbers. Last week, 400 were killed, officials say.
articles.abstract: The Taliban is killing Afghan soldiers and police officers in record numbers. Last week, 400 were killed, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUL-I-KUMRI, Afghanistan — Taliban insurgents killed so many Afghan security forces in 2016, an average of 22 a day, that by the following year the Afghan and American governments decided to keep battlefield death tolls secret.

articles.headline: These Robots Run, Dance and Flip. But Are They a Business?
articles.snippet: Boston Dynamics often makes a splash with videos of its anthropomorphic robots. But after years of work, it is not clear who would buy them or what they would be used for.
articles.abstract: Boston Dynamics often makes a splash with videos of its anthropomorphic robots. But after years of work, it is not clear who would buy them or what they would be used for.
articles.lead_paragraph: WALTHAM, Mass. — Moving like a large dog, knees bent and hips swaying, the robot walked across a parking lot and into a rain puddle.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz and Max Aguilera-Hellweg

articles.headline: 25 Years After Escobar’s Death, Medellín Struggles to Demolish a Legend
articles.snippet: If the Colombian city cannot bury the memory of the drug lord Pablo Escobar, it at least wants to control how and where his story gets told.
articles.abstract: If the Colombian city cannot bury the memory of the drug lord Pablo Escobar, it at least wants to control how and where his story gets told.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEDELLÍN, Colombia — When the mayor of Medellín showed up, he was bearing a sledgehammer.

articles.headline: China and Vatican Reach Deal on Appointment of Bishops
articles.snippet: For the first time, the pope accepted the legitimacy of bishops chosen by the Communist Chinese government.
articles.abstract: For the first time, the pope accepted the legitimacy of bishops chosen by the Communist Chinese government.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — The Vatican said Saturday that it had reached a provisional deal with the Chinese government to end a decades-old power struggle over the right to appoint bishops in China. It was the Communist country’s first formal recognition of the pope’s authority within the Roman Catholic Church in the world’s most populous nation, Vatican officials said.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Ian Johnson

articles.headline: Sheldon Adelson Sees a Lot to Like in Trump’s Washington
articles.snippet: The casino magnate and his wife, initially skeptical of President Trump, are thrilled with some of his policies and have donated $55 million to Republican campaigns.
articles.abstract: The casino magnate and his wife, initially skeptical of President Trump, are thrilled with some of his policies and have donated $55 million to Republican campaigns.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The return on investment for many of the Republican Party’s biggest political patrons has been less than impressive this year. But not for Sheldon Adelson.

articles.headline: Tentative Deal Reached for Christine Blasey Ford to Testify on Thursday
articles.snippet: The decision by the woman, Christine Blasey Ford, came after days of uncertainty over whether she would appear at a hearing and answer questions about her accusations of sexual assault.
articles.abstract: The decision by the woman, Christine Blasey Ford, came after days of uncertainty over whether she would appear at a hearing and answer questions about her accusations of sexual assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate Judiciary Committee and lawyers for the woman who has accused Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh of sexually assaulting her decades ago reached a tentative agreement on Saturday for her to publicly testify on Thursday, an apparent breakthrough that could alter the course of a bitter confirmation fight.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Trump Galvanized a Movement of Women. Kavanaugh Is Testing It.
articles.snippet: The judge’s fate, and the Senate’s treatment of his accuser, have the makings of a pivot point in American politics — a wrenching apex in the struggle over the status of American women and abortion.
articles.abstract: The judge’s fate, and the Senate’s treatment of his accuser, have the makings of a pivot point in American politics — a wrenching apex in the struggle over the status of American women and abortion.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his first appearance before the nation, Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh positioned himself as an ally of social change for women in America. Standing beside President Trump at the White House, Judge Kavanaugh spoke of being a father of daughters and a coach to a girls’ basketball team. He hailed his mother’s legal career. He boasted that most of his clerks had been women.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns, Elizabeth Dias and Susan Chira

articles.headline: Kavanaugh Was Supposed to Be a Midterm Boon for G.O.P. Not Anymore.
articles.snippet: Republican leaders in battleground states like Missouri are increasingly doubtful that candidates can wield the court nomination as a cudgel without risking repercussions.
articles.abstract: Republican leaders in battleground states like Missouri are increasingly doubtful that candidates can wield the court nomination as a cudgel without risking repercussions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Mo. — No Republican Senate candidate has been as aggressive in using the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh as a political weapon as Josh Hawley, the Missouri attorney general who is in an intensely tight race against Senator Claire McCaskill.

articles.headline: China Is Confronting New U.S. Hostility. But Is It Ready for the Fight?
articles.snippet: As the acrimony intensifies, Beijing’s immediate worry is how the Chinese public will handle the trade war and what impact it might have on domestic stability.
articles.abstract: As the acrimony intensifies, Beijing’s immediate worry is how the Chinese public will handle the trade war and what impact it might have on domestic stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese leader, wearing a dark Mao suit, and the American president, in a black tuxedo, stood side by side with arms aloft at the Kennedy Center. Deng Xiaoping and Jimmy Carter smiled broadly as the orchestra played “Getting to Know You,” signaling the dawn of a new era of friendship and cooperation between their two nations.

articles.headline: Christine Blasey Ford Reaches Deal to Testify at Kavanaugh Hearing
articles.snippet: Some details on the agreement still needed to be finalized, but her lawyers said those would not impede her testifying Thursday on her accusation of sexual assault.
articles.abstract: Some details on the agreement still needed to be finalized, but her lawyers said those would not impede her testifying Thursday on her accusation of sexual assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The woman who has accused Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh of sexually assaulting her when they were teenagers has committed to testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday, setting up a potentially explosive confrontation unlike any seen in decades with the future of the Supreme Court at stake.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Trump at the U.N.: Undiplomatic? This Time, Aides Fear the Opposite
articles.snippet: The president’s advisers worry that he will be overly enthusiastic about engagement with adversaries, given his conviction that he can outmaneuver any leader or strike any deal.
articles.abstract: The president’s advisers worry that he will be overly enthusiastic about engagement with adversaries, given his conviction that he can outmaneuver any leader or strike any deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump made his first visit to the United Nations last year, he ridiculed North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, as a suicidal “rocket man” and threatened to “totally destroy” his country. He also vowed to rip up the Iran nuclear deal, which he called an “embarrassment to the United States.”
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: App-Only Banks Rise in Europe and Aim at Traditional Lenders
articles.snippet: Favorable regulations and an influx of venture capital have made London a testing ground for banks without physical branches.
articles.abstract: Favorable regulations and an influx of venture capital have made London a testing ground for banks without physical branches.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Greg Stevenson was trying to refinance the mortgage on his four-bedroom home in eastern England when things started going awry. An attempt by his bank, TSB, to shift data to a new computer system had gone spectacularly wrong. For several maddening days, he could not connect to his account, transfer funds or reach anybody at the bank for help.

articles.headline: Want to See What’s Up Amazon’s Sleeve? Take a Tour of Seattle
articles.snippet: The e-commerce giant uses its headquarters city as a living laboratory, trying out new retail and logistics models.
articles.abstract: The e-commerce giant uses its headquarters city as a living laboratory, trying out new retail and logistics models.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Tourists in Seattle have a new must-see destination: Amazon Go, the cashierless store the company opened near downtown in January.

articles.headline: In Beating Disney for Sky, Comcast Remains in the Game
articles.snippet: Gaining control of the British pay-TV company was key for Comcast’s future plans, but it came at a steep price and Disney still has 21st Century Fox’s assets.
articles.abstract: Gaining control of the British pay-TV company was key for Comcast’s future plans, but it came at a steep price and Disney still has 21st Century Fox’s assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Comcast and the Walt Disney Company have long been rivals. But Brian L. Roberts, who runs Comcast, has recently become the Magic Kingdom’s nemesis in chief.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Edmund Lee

articles.headline: Trump’s China Fight Puts U.S. Tech in the Cross Hairs
articles.snippet: As tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese goods go into effect on Monday, tech and telecom companies warn that America’s dominance is at risk.
articles.abstract: As tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese goods go into effect on Monday, tech and telecom companies warn that America’s dominance is at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump says his trade war with China will protect America’s dominance and derail Beijing’s plan for technological and economic supremacy.

articles.headline: With Vatican Talks and Bulldozers, China Aims to Control Christianity
articles.snippet: The moves to assert control over Catholic and Protestant churches reflect a broader effort to establish control over society under President Xi Jinping.
articles.abstract: The moves to assert control over Catholic and Protestant churches reflect a broader effort to establish control over society under President Xi Jinping.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Over the last two years, China’s estimated 60 million Christians have felt the power of a newly assertive government eager to bring their faith to heel.

articles.headline: Trump’s Tariffs May Hurt, but Quitting China Is Hard to Do
articles.snippet: Companies are reconsidering where to put their factories as the trade war mounts, but few places can match China’s convenience and reliability.
articles.abstract: Companies are reconsidering where to put their factories as the trade war mounts, but few places can match China’s convenience and reliability.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — The worsening trade war between the United States and China has intensified pressure on companies to leave China and set up factories in places like Cambodia, a verdant country of 16 million people with low wages and high hopes.

articles.headline: Rod Rosenstein’s Job Is Safe, for Now: Inside His Dramatic Day
articles.snippet: Mr. Rosenstein talked last year about invoking the 25th Amendment to remove the president and secretly taping him. Those conversations were revealed last week.
articles.abstract: Mr. Rosenstein talked last year about invoking the 25th Amendment to remove the president and secretly taping him. Those conversations were revealed last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general, headed to the White House on Monday morning, he was ready to resign and convinced — wrongly, it turned out — that President Trump was about to fire him. Top Justice Department aides scrambled to draft a statement about who would succeed him.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Katie Benner, Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt
